paragraphs.name: 402c
paragraphs.text: Thanks for this, nice tutorial on both HOC and animation development patterns.

Also noticed a bit of text blurring during the animation, believe its related to the centering css on the main app div causing issues with the font aliasing, particularly when it lands on sub-pixel destination coordinates (in latest Mac Chrome)…

paragraphs.name: 05b8
paragraphs.text: Great job. Small typo where you give an example to install `react-animations` you instead write `npm-install — save react-motion`.

paragraphs.name: d53b
paragraphs.text: Unfortunately I don’t know. I don’t see any blurring, so I wonder if there is a font issue or something else going on with material-ui that is causing the problem. The font is Roboto, which should be pretty common, but weird things can happen with fonts.
good to know. thanks

cf67d77254a6.title: After you introduce React Motion, all of the npm commands you provide start out “npm-install…

paragraphs.name: 5d9e
paragraphs.text: After you introduce React Motion, all of the npm commands you provide start out “npm-install” instead of “npm install” as it should be. I just wanted to point this out for anyone that might be copying and pasting your CLI commands. Also, after you introduce React Animations your CLI command is npm install --save react-motion when I believe you mean npm install --save react-animations.

9079e28df1e0.title: Do you know why the text looks so blurry when the animation is in-progress?

paragraphs.name: b895
paragraphs.text: Do you know why the text looks so blurry when the animation is in-progress?

paragraphs.name: 2aeb
paragraphs.text: Hi there,
great great post!

paragraphs.name: 3c49
paragraphs.text: The little blur effect is due to the component width and CSS centering function. As the component (on Win-Chrome) is 345px wide (347 including borders) the browser struggles to centre it, hence the blur effect.

ab8479df9dbc.title: Are you referring to the live demo or the animated gif in the post?
